title.value: Exploring validation metrics for offline model-based optimisation with diffusion models
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Exploring validation metrics for offline model-based optimisation with diffusion models

extractions.description: This paper discusses the evaluation of denoising diffusion models in the context of offline model-based optimization (MBO). It introduces an evaluation framework to find validation metrics that correlate well with the ground truth oracle in MBO. The study also focuses on using denoising diffusion models due to their state-of-the-art performance and derives insights from the empirical evaluation of these models across several datasets and metrics.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical evaluation of different validation metrics on diffusion models and discusses results from actual experiments and datasets.
type.quote: While our evaluation framework is model agnostic we specifically evaluate denoising diffusion models due to their state-of-the-art performance, as well as derive interesting insights such as ranking the most effective validation metrics as well as discussing important hyperparameters.

name.justification: The paper revolves around model-based optimization using machine learning, specifically focusing on denoising diffusion models.
name.quote: In model-based optimisation (MBO), we wish to learn a model of some unknown objective function f : X → Y where f is the ground truth ‘oracle’.

name.justification: The paper evaluates generative models, particularly denoising diffusion models, within the context of MBO.
name.quote: While our proposed evaluation framework is agnostic to the class of generative model, we specifically demonstrate it using the recently-proposed class of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs).

name.justification: The paper specifically experiments with denoising diffusion models, a type of generative model.
name.quote: we specifically demonstrate it using the recently-proposed class of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs)

name.justification: The paper focuses on evaluating denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) for offline MBO tasks.
name.quote: While our proposed evaluation framework is agnostic to the class of generative model, we specifically demonstrate it using the recently-proposed class of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs).

is_contributed.justification: The paper evaluates denoising diffusion probabilistic models rather than introducing them.
is_contributed.quote: we specifically demonstrate it using the recently-proposed class of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs)

is_executed.justification: The paper involves the execution of denoising diffusion models in different experimental settings.
is_executed.quote: While our evaluation framework is model agnostic we specifically evaluate denoising diffusion models due to their state-of-the-art performance

is_compared.justification: The study ranks and compares the effectiveness of various validation metrics with respect to the models.
is_compared.quote: we examine two conditional variants: classifier-based (Dhariwal & Nichol, 2021) and classifier-free (Ho & Salimans, 2022) guidance.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper is cited as the foundational work on denoising diffusion models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: While our proposed evaluation framework is agnostic to the class of generative model, we specifically demonstrate it using the recently-proposed class of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) (Ho et al., 2020).

name.justification: The datasets are sourced from the Design Bench framework, with four datasets being specifically examined.
name.quote: We explore five validation metrics in our work against four datasets in the Design Bench (Trabucco et al., 2022) framework

referenced_paper_title.value: Design-bench: Benchmarks for data-driven offline model-based optimization
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper cites Trabucco et al. 2022 as the source of Design Bench.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We explore five validation metrics in our work against four datasets in the Design Bench (Trabucco et al., 2022) framework

name.justification: While PMLR is more of a publication venue, it indirectly supports the study by hosting related papers referenced in the context of datasets and benchmarks.
name.quote: In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp. 10358–10368. PMLR, 2021.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Referenced as the source citing the Design Bench framework.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp. 10358–10368. PMLR, 2021.
